title: How to publish a book on my own in India - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi there, Disclaimer First: I am one of the founders @ Notion Press Publishing. If you have already written your book, you have a few options. 1. You could approach traditional publishers like Penguin, Harper Collins, Hachette etc. who are all renowned names in traditional publishing, and submit your manuscript for a review. However, traditional publishers get bombarded with hundreds of manuscripts and take a long time to even go through them ( if at all they do ). More often than not, they also reject first time authors such as yourself due to a perceived risk of publishing an unknown name. 2. You could subsequently approach any self-publishing platform similar to Notion Press and work with a team of book experts who will take care of the entire publishing process and bring both the print and eBook version of your book out to the market. In this guided publishing model, you will own 100% of the rights to the book and take home 100% of the profits from book sales. Notion Press has published close to 4000 first time writers so far in the span of 6 years. To know more about how this works you can check out the website link given above. 3. Your third option would be to publish it by yourself by using platforms like Kindle Direct Publishing or Createspace. These are essentially do-it-yourself platforms which would essentially require you to take care of every aspect of publishing ie. cover design, interior formatting, editing etc by yourself. Once you have all these things in place, you can just upload it onto the platform and they will compile it as a book and you can start selling it on online stores. Such platforms are mostly free to use and take a commission from each book’s sale and pay remaining profit as royalty.

You don’t really need any formal qualifications to be a published author (unless you’re writing an academic text or a self-help book. For fiction, you only need to be a good story teller with an interesting book.) I’ll be talking about traditional publishing (where you approach an established publishing house) a work of fiction. One can self-publish if they like, but I’m not well versed with that. There are pros and cons to self publishing as well as traditional publishing. So make sure to do your research first. Alright so, the steps—  You write a book, duh. You edit it to the best of your abilities. You make sure the plot is well structured and the characters are well-constructed. Also keep an eye out on the genre and the length of your book and research a little. For instance, Contemporary Romance novels are generally 60,000 to 90,000 words in length. Make sure to find out a little about the ideal length for your genre and try not to exceed it too much.  Scope out publishers. Of course, we’d all like to get published by one of the big publishing houses but it’s not that easy. So to be on the safe side, look up some smaller publishing houses too. Check out their websites (don’t trust publishing houses that don’t have a decent and informative website, in my opinion.) See the kind of books they’ve published in the past. Check their ratings, sales and reviews on amazon and goodreads to get some idea of their success. If you’ve written a science-fiction novel, pay attention to their scifi books. How well did they perform in the market? Read a sample on amazon if it’s available to figure out the level of writing this publishing house seeks. Another thing you should try to find out are their marketing strategies. Look up their social media handles. See how they’ve promoted books in the past. Have they held any events? What are their techniques. If the publishing house seems to have a good marketing strategy and has had decent amount of sales for books in your genre, you should consider it.  Next, the procedure. You can find manuscript submission guidelines on the publisher’s website itself. They might differ from publisher to publisher, but usually all of them have similar requirements. They either have an in-built form for manuscript submission or they provide an email. Some of them actually demand physical copies instead of soft-copies. Some of them (usually the big ones) do not accept manuscripts from writers at all. Instead, they demand the author should have a literary agent who pitches the novel first (this is rare in India though.) Basically, read the submission guidelines. It’ll give you all the information.  What you’ll generally have to do is write an email to the publisher. Every publisher has their own requirement but usually you’ll have to write a synopsis for your novel, a summary of the novel and attach a designated number of chapter (3–5 usually.) Some publishers directly ask you to send the whole novel. Basically, read the submission guideline carefully and follow it up properly otherwise your email won’t even be read. I won’t get into giving you tips to write that email, I’m not experienced enough. But it’s basically you marketing your own book to the publisher. You must be able to convince them with your synopsis or pitch (which is basically a 30–50 word long para that accurately describes what your book is about, that your book is worth reading and that they ought to give it a chance. This is extremely important with big publishing houses who get lots of manuscripts and emails, so they cannot read all of them.  If your book is rejected, you might get an email stating so in a few weeks time from small publishing houses. The big ones might not even reply. The publishers usually mention a time period on their website, stating if you don’t get a response by then, you can assume your book was declined. In case you are accepted, someone from the publishing house will contact you and ask you to send the rest of the manuscript so they can do a close reading of it. Now this doesn’t mean your book has been approved. But it means they are interested, that they found your book marketable and it appears to be well-written. If the rest of your book is as promising as the first few chapters, you’ll probably get a publishing deal. Now publishing houses are very adamant about one thing—if they’re doing a close reading of your manuscript, no other publisher should be doing it. They don’t want to waste their energy on reading your book only to find out you rejected them later for another publisher. So you’re expected to inform them at this point if any other publisher has also shown interest. In the rare occasion that you have more than one publishers interested, you’ll have to make a decision and say no to one. This is why it’s not advised to send your book to too many publishers at the same time, especially if you’re dealing with larger publishing houses. Also tip, don’t immediately send out your first email to your number one publisher. Start with a smaller house. In case you get rejected by them, you’ll know you need to work on your book or improve your pitch (you could ask them for feedback/review.) In case you’re accepted, you can either go ahead with them or take a risk and send your work to a bigger publisher.  Big publishing houses usually take six months to read your manuscript closely. Smaller publishing houses might take lesser time. You can inquire from time to time, but don’t pester them with emails. Let them take their time. Unfortunately, you could still get rejected after six months of waiting and then you’ll have to start all over again with other publishers. In case you’re accepted, they’ll offer you a publishing contract. Make sure to read it very carefully. Do your research and don’t be afraid of asking them questions and clarifications. You might be able to negotiate the contract with smaller publishing houses, but don’t even try with the big ones. Once you find everything to your liking, you can sign it and you’ve gotten your contract. But there’s still a lot to be done!  They’ll probably provide you with detail feedback for your novel. They might request you to re-edit your book or make some changes, after which your book will be sent to an in-house publisher who will edit it further and then probably send it back to your for a final look-over. Your work load from here will probably decrease. Since it’s the traditional way, just sit back and relax a little. The publisher will figure out when the book can be launched, they’ll figure out marketing tactics and the cover (they might ask for your input in this but they’re not obliged to.) They’ll even set up your website or Facebook page if you don’t have one.  Once everything is planned and ready, they’ll get ready to launch your book. They’ll hold some promos and marketing events if they have enough resources. You might or might not have to be a part of these events, it depends on their strategy. They might even give out pre-published copies of your book for free to select reviewers to generate discussion around your book in media and to generate reviews on amazon and goodreads to further promote sales. They might hold a book launch event if they’re a big publishing house.  Once your book gets launched, you don’t have to do much. They’ll handle reviews and advertisements. You might be asked to post stuff from time to time or engage with your readers. Once your book generates the decided amount (stated in the contract) through sales, you’ll be eligible to get paid. You might be paid once or twice a year in bulk (this varies from publisher to publisher.) I guess that’s about it! Hope this was helpful. Just make sure to do your research. Don’t get too excited and jump into a publishing deal.

Hi, this is one of the most asked questions all around the world. That how can I become an author? How can I publish my own book? No publishing company wants to work with me……. and so on. The reason why all the publishing company or let say few of them don't want to work with an amateur is that they don’t know the reaction of the readers about that particular author. Similarly, in our Bollywood, you have to work hard to make your place similarly is the literature world. Either you have a great fan following on social media or you are a well-known writer of the century then only the publishing house wants to gamble on you. So, the question is how I can publish my own book without going to a publishing house and the answer for you is to go for self-publishing. Now the case is that you might be the best storyteller in the world and I believe you are. But you can’t be a one-man army, what I want to say is you can’t be your own editor, beta-reader, book cover designer, book interior designer, social media marketer, and so on. Suppose you have finished your manuscript and you know what you have completed it because you love the storyline since it was in your mind you think that the story is believable since you wrote it you think there are no mistake because it’s human nature that we cannot point out our own mistakes. Am I correct? Yup, that is what human nature is. So, first of all, go for the beta-readers, you can find them on Instagram or any other social media platform, or else you can higher them from Fiverr or any other freelancing site. After beta reading you should go for editor, you will find lots of them who are willing to work and can find out the mistake and improve them at the same time. Once you are done with them start looking for someone who can format your book for KDP, Createspace, Lullu. These all are the self-publishing platforms where you can publish your book without any hesitation. Also at the same time ask a graphic designer to design a cover for your book as per the industrial requirement. Hire a social media marketer to do marketting of your book on social media because “जो दिखता है वही बिकता है" Upload the details on the website on kindle or Createspace or any of the self-publishing platform that you like. Hit publish and you are done. Hope this helps!

I have seen many writers aspiring to self-publish their book which is really great to see. But the major drawback I feel is that none of them ever know the true method of self-publishing. I don’t blame anyone for that because, when it comes to self-publishing, the first results which the google would produce are all the vanity publishers, who claim to publish your book by offering some fancy packages (Which aren’t really fancy) and few worthwhile services. PLEASE NOTE, THAT IS NOT THE ENTIRE CONCEPT OF SELF-PUBLISHING! They are what you say the middlemen who’d help you with all the services you require in return for your money and also royalty on every sale! Want to know what is REAL SELF-PUBLISHING? READ ALONG. A self-publishing author or more commonly known as an Indie-Author would finish his manuscript, Find an editor by himself, find a cover artist by himself and then instead of approaching any publishing company he/she would approach the PRINTING PRESS. Any local as well as well-known printing company will offer to print your books at reasonable rates if you order in bulk. I’d say they’d offer you between 500 copies, 1000 or 2000 copies. Print on Demand (POD) would be too costly for you. By far I am guessing that since you are opting for self-publishing your book that means you’d at least have a budget of around 1 lac rupees which is more than enough and which could be easily recovered in the 1st or 2nd month of your book release (If you have good sales, that is if you have a ready made audience or marketing plan). That’s it! Once you make a deal with the printing company. take care of all other requirements such as Typesetting your book and ebook creation (Generally a professional would offer both things hand in hand at a reasonable rate). Next step is to get copyrights which is easy if you just google it and lastly, ISBN number which can be obtained for free as well. And there you go! Get your book printed, start an Amazon seller account, boost your sales through pre-orders and follow your marketing plan lead. Once you have a decent sale on amazon, you can approach the local book stores as well who’d be willing to keep your books as far as it is returnable*. THIS PROCEDURE IS THE REAL WAY OF SELF-PUBLISHING. For some of you it may sound as a lengthy or a tiresome process but trust me if you really believe in your story and the years/months of hard-work which you have done for it, then this approach would be one of the best experience for you and WAY BETTER than those vanity publishers who claim to be NO. 1 publishers. Look at the reality, how many authors have fallen for their traps and almost given up on their writing careers. Things are really different in India when it comes to the publishing industry, so beware, look for the right things, right approach. I’ll soon post an article on my website about this matter. I hope whoever reads this, it helps you and trust in yourself and your story, You can do it (:

There are two ways you could publish your book: Traditional publishingSelf-publishingI do not have experience with traditional publishing. However, you could consider self-publishing, like I did. All major self-publishing platforms also support authors from India. Here are some that you can try. Self-publish your book to Amazon's Kindle Store - free to self-publishEbooks from independent authors and publishers - free to self-publishDraft2Digital | Welcome - free to self-publishGoogle Books - free to self-publishFor print books, a print on demand service like CreateSpace (free to self-publish) is probably the best bet, but delivery to India might be expensive compared to the US, Canada and Europe. If you are looking for an Indian company to help with publishing, Self Publishing and Print on Demand in India (free service if you can provide fully formatted content) or Book Publishers in India (paid service) could be considered. Royalties on KDP, the largest marketplace for eBooks vary from 35% to 70% depending on the pricing of the book, the country in which the purchase is made and also based on whether you enroll in KDP Select (where you have to keep your books exclusive to Amazon). Details are available at the link provided above. Royalties on other platforms vary from 30% to 60%. There are no legal issues that I am aware of, other than the fact that income from royalties will be taxable in India. Also look at the pros and cons of self-publishing vs. traditional publishing below. Self Publishing Pros Better control of the publishing process - complete creative freedom to choose what you want to include and howBetter royalties - no cut for the publisher. You decide your pricing and royalties. eBook royalties can be as high as 70%.Faster to market - you can self-publish an eBook that you have ready in a matter of minutes and make it available worldwideNo restrictions for newbie authorsCons Discoverability - your book is the proverbial needle in the haystackMarketing - you are responsible for all marketing effortsIf you are opting for a print edition, there might be an upfront cost involved - except in the case of Print-on-demand optionTraditional Publishing Pros You have the backing of a reputed publishing house - better discoverabilityMarketing is part of the book publishing deal and the publisher helps to an extentProfessional editing, formatting and cover designMade available through all major bookstores and online retailersCons Can take a significant amount of time (months) to get a book to the marketNew authors might find it difficult to get the backing of a good publisher - others might charge a one time publishing fee starting from INR 25,000.Lower royalties - 10 - 15% of selling price for print editionsDo feel free to let me know if you have any specific questions. Good luck with your book!

To Publish a book on your own, you must first get a license for publication.Self-Publishing process involves a number of steps including editing, formatting, cover designing, proofreading etc. So, either you need to hire someone who is expert in this field and then after getting a copy ready, approach a printing press to get it printed under your Imprint. This is basically the gist of Self-Publishing process. However, there are a number of self-publishing agencies that charge you or sell you a package including a few services associated with the processes mentioned above and get your printed. These agencies act as the mediator and this doesn’t make you a self-published author. You get published under a self-publishing company. Might seem confusing but self-publishing actually means getting your published under your own publication house. In India, there are many self-publishing agencies. A few of them charge hefty sums and provide services of book publishing and a few can do it for free but in that case, you’ll have to prepare your book in the print ready format along with the cover. They will do nothing but give it an ISBN and put it on sale under their imprint. You can also get your book published in E-book format and for that, I’d suggest you to opt Amazon Kindle. The platform is easy to use and you won’t have to face much troubles. But for paperback, you can either start your own publication house (Which of course is another BIG deal) or go for any of these middle agents. Caution: Choose your publisher wisely as many of these vanity publishers are the scavengers on hunt. Feel free to drop in for any other query. All The Best!

Your book is the fruit of your toil - Days and nights spent brainstorming, thinking, writing, editing, proofreading, reediting and what not. The task of choosing the right publisher therefore is a crucial step in ensuring that your book reaches the reader's platform the right way with the right message. And for that to be possible, you need to be well versed in the various factors and criteria you should be putting your attention to, while choosing the best publisher for your book.Researching publishers is an important step in the entire process to choosing a good publisher for your book - It helps you keep tabs on the requirements, marketing strategies and ethos, book contacting terms and conditions, the various steps to publishing in different publishing companies to be able to calculate on your own the suitability of a particular publisher for your book. The editor's compatibility with the vision of your book, the publisher's track record with similar books, the financial terms and conditions including advance and royalty considerations are important aspects to be examined before settling on a publisher for your book. It is therefore really necessary that you do your homework and research well before deciding on a publisher for your book. 105 Views · View Upvoters ·

You can purchase an ISBN either from an organization like Bowker or from a self-publishing company (see How do I obtain an ISBN Number? and How can I get an ISBN number in India? How long does it usually take? Are there any good agencies that will get it done for me?). There is a difference with where you buy your ISBN from. If you buy your ISBN from a self-publishing company, they own the ISBN typically. This means that you can only print your books through them. I caught by this myself, and it forced me to switch ISBNs. It's much cheaper though ($10 US typically).If you buy your ISBN directly from Bowker, you will pay a lot more for it ($250 US). But, you'll have a lot more flexibility with it. You can then take your book to anyone to print -- or to multiple people at the same time.Once you have an ISBN, you can print the book from a self-publishing company. In India, Abhaya Agarwal's company Pothi.com is fantastic. I've had a great experience with them. You can print on demand, so you don't have to pay upfront for large print runs. They can also help you get your book up on websites like Flipkart.com. Within the US, you can use CreateSpace, which will help you get your book up on Amazon. That's it. There's no special legal work or anything like that to go through. (However, if you're serious about this, I do recommend investing in professional layout, editing, etc. It does get expensive though.)
